Title: If You Need to Support Clients Over the Internet, Consider Using Message Security
DirectLink: If You Need to Support Clients Over the Internet, Consider Using Message Security
Priority: J.D. Meier, Jason Taylor, Prashant Bansode, Carlos Farre, Madhu Sundararajan, Rob Boucher, Steve Gregersen

Data:
Applies to

  • Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5
  • Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

What to Do

If you need to support clients over the Internet, consider using Message Security.

Why

Message security provides end to end security.

When

Consider using this guideline when you need to support clients over the Internet.

How

Use message security when your clients are deployed over internet and you cannot rely on TLS.  Message security provides end to end security. 

  • TLS does not provide protection for the initial client-server handshake. Thus a man-in-the-middle attack can go undetected.
  • You have less control of the communication between the client and service across the Internet. There is a chance of having intermediaries which might break transport security.

The downside of using message security is potentially decreased performance due to the fact that each message much be encrypted individually. Large message packets can especially create lag. You can use wsHttpBinding which by default uses message security and also supports interoperability as it uses text encoding.
